title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" allows for grants to states for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and families expecting children. This Act aims to support quality home visitation programs for these families. The "Early Support for Families Act" aims to improve the well-being of children by funding quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States must submit a grant application describing the programs, intended outcomes, and evidence of effectiveness to receive funding. The grant under the "Early Support for Families Act" will support high-quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. A statewide needs assessment will provide information on the number, quality, and capacity of these programs, eligible families receiving services, funding sources, and gaps in early childhood home visitation. The State will provide a needs assessment for home visitation programs, including information on eligible families, funding sources, gaps in services, and training activities. Assurances are required to prioritize serving communities in need. The State must prioritize serving communities in need, reserve 5% of grant funds for training, and promote coordination with other child services in supporting home visitation programs. The State must prioritize serving communities in need, reserve 5% of grant funds for training, promote coordination with other child services, and provide referrals to other programs serving children and families. From the amount reserved for Indian tribes, the Secretary shall allot funds based on the number of children in the tribe whose families have income below 200% of the poverty line. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in the State whose families have income below 200% of the poverty line. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in the State whose families have income below 200% of the poverty line. Any unspent funds by a State will be reallotted to other States based on specified methodology. The State certifies funds not used will be reallotted. States must maintain expenditure levels for home visitation programs. The Secretary will grant funds to States meeting requirements. The Secretary will make a grant to States meeting requirements for home visitation programs, with the grant amount based on eligible expenditures and allotted funds. The reimbursable percentage for fiscal year 2010 is 85 percent. The reimbursable percentage for fiscal year 2010 is 85 percent, decreasing to 80 percent in 2011 and 75 percent in 2012 onwards. Eligible expenditures refer to funds used for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children or expecting children. Expenditures for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children or expecting children must adhere to evidence-based models, employ well-trained staff, and demonstrate strong organizational capacity. Expenditures for voluntary home visitation programs for families with young children must adhere to evidence-based models, employ well-trained staff, and demonstrate strong organizational capacity, including appropriate linkages to community resources and supports. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence base. Priority funding is given to voluntary home visitation programs with the strongest evidence base. Expenditures for training, technical assistance, and evaluations related to the programs must adhere to evidence-based models. Expenditures for programs that do not adhere to a model of home visitation with the strongest evidence of effectiveness may not be considered eligible if they exceed the applicable percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year. Eligible expenditures exceeding the applicable percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year are defined by specific percentages for each fiscal year. States receiving grants under this section cannot use other federal funds for the state match. The State's allotment for eligible expenditures is defined by specific percentages for each fiscal year, such as 50 percent for 2012, 45 percent for 2013, and 40 percent for 2014. States receiving grants under this section cannot use other federal funds for the state match, and the Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions for Indian tribes under certain circumstances. The State must submit annual reports on the progress of programs funded by grants under this section. Indian tribes can have provisions waived or modified by the Secretary if it imposes an undue burden. The State must submit an annual report to the Secretary on the progress of programs funded by grants under this section. The report should include details on services delivered, program characteristics, provider qualifications, recipient demographics, and program costs. The annual report to the Secretary must include details on program outcomes, costs, recipient demographics, training provided, and program implementation monitoring. The Secretary shall conduct an independent evaluation of home visitation programs to assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, and school readiness. The evaluation will also examine the effectiveness of these programs. The Secretary will evaluate home visitation programs' impact on child and parent outcomes, including maltreatment, health, development, and school readiness. The evaluation will also assess the effectiveness of these programs and report to Congress within 2 years. The Secretary will submit an interim report to Congress within 2 years and a final report within 4 years on the evaluation of home visitation programs. Additionally, annual reports on activities funded under this section, including targeting high-need communities, will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must annually report to Congress on activities funded under this section, detailing high-need communities targeted, service delivery models, program characteristics, and reported outcomes. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on activities funded under this section, including program staff characteristics, recipient characteristics, outcomes, research-based instruction, training activities, costs, and monitoring methods used by States. The annual costs of implementing the programs, including cost per family served, indicators and methods for monitoring program implementation, reservations of funds for evaluation, training, and grants to Indian tribes. The Secretary is appropriated funds for early childhood home visitation programs, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2010 to 2014. Additionally, grants are provided to Indian tribes under this section. Indian tribes are treated as states for the purposes of this section.
